results.title: Water polo: Montreal Olympics
results.creator_credit: Dennis A. Hill, Dennis Hill Productions and Barry Williams
results.brief_description: Includes excerpts from final rounds of water polo played between West Germany and Rumania, Hungary and Yugoslavia, Hungary and Italy, Italy and Holland during the Montreal Olympics held in 1976. Also includes a visual demonstration of training methods and rules and techniques as explained by the Dutch coach.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis A. Hill, Dennis Hill Productions and Barry Williams

results.title: Water polo
results.brief_description: A detailed examination of isolated movements in water polo, including lifting, catching, and returning the ball, leg action during a throw, and various forms of tackle. The distribution of players in the pool, and various methods of positioning and attacking and defending are shown both by direct photography and the use of animation. Players include Dr Sutton, the English captain, Martin, North, and Pascoe, international players, and members of the Plaistow and Oxford and Cambridge Universities Water Polo teams.

results.title: Water pollution: a first film
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Follows a single stream from its origin to its end in order to reveal the many different sources of pollution. Points out that individuals as well as groups can help clean up water resources.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BFA Educational Media and Norman Bean Films

results.title: Water movement in soils
results.creator_credit: Washington State University, W.E. Gardner and J.C. Haish
results.brief_description: The demonstration, using a model of a vertical section through the soil and time lapse photography, shows how liquid moves through soil of various compositions. The elements of the soil, which control the movement of water and liquid fertiliser, are of major importance in agriculture, irrigation, erosion control etc.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Washington State University, W.E. Gardner and J.C. Haish

results.title: Water is the key
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmanian State Film Unit and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: Shows the many uses to which water, Tasmania’s greatest natural resource, is put, including generation of hydro-electric power, irrigation, and industrial and domestic consumption.

results.title: Water into gold
results.brief_description: Discusses Australia’s water resources in terms of storage and usage. Examines different methods of irrigation, and depicts irrigation systems and areas in Victoria.

results.title: Water in Bogor
results.creator_credit: John Morris, Film Australia and Brian Hannant
results.brief_description: Bogor, a large bustling city one hour’s drive from Jakarta, is one of the highest rainfall areas on earth. This film records the progress of one of the projects in the program of Australia’s aid to Indonesia: providing Bogor with a clean water supply.

results.title: Water in biology
results.creator_credit: Peter Bradford, World Wide Pictures and David Morphet
results.brief_description: Explains the basic role of water in all living organisms due to its solvent properties and physical behaviour, covering diffusion, osmosis, solute balance, transpiration and photosynthesis. The relationship between water and life is essential to an industry concerned with large scale food production.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Bradford, World Wide Pictures and David Morphet
